Column: 1971

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

INFLATION AND DECLINING INTEREST RATES

(Impact on Singapore households)

     1.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Finance (a) what is the outlook for interest rates in Singapore for 2011; (b) what percentage of the population above 55 years old have only saving deposits as their assets, apart from their homes; and (c) what can be done to help this group of people to get more returns on their savings.

     2.  Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for Finance with inflation at its highest level since January 2009 and expected to rise in 2011, (a) what will be the impact on Singaporeans on low or fixed incomes, such as retirees, and what can be done to assist them to cope with the cost of living; and (b) how Singaporeans can be encouraged to save, given the low returns on savings from banks.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam):  Mr Speaker, may I take Question Nos. 1 and 2 together?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  Ms Irene Ng referred to the impact of higher inflation on Singaporeans.  CPI inflation for November 2010 was 3.8% year-on-year, bringing the average over January to November to 2.7%.  It is expected to rise further in the first quarter of this year, before moderating in subsequent quarters.

 

     However, about half of the "headline CPI inflation rate" over the last year has been due to a single factor – the sharp rise in COE premiums.  This CPI increase hence does not mean a similar increase in

Column: 1972

actual cash outlays by the majority of Singaporeans, as only 3% to 4% of households, or 7% of all car owners, purchased new COEs in 2010.  The majority of car owners hold existing COEs.  If COE premiums stay high, everyone who purchases a new car or renews a COE will eventually face this higher price.  However, the purchases will take place over a period of years.  Hence, the impact on cash outlays for households as a whole will be spread out over a few years.

 

     Excluding the recent increase in COE premiums – which contributed significantly to the "headline CPI inflation rate" – inflation during January to November 2010 averaged about 1.3%.  It was due mainly to increases in prices of various foods and oil-related items in the household consumption basket.  These price increases reflected weather-related disruptions in food supply from abroad, increased demand in emerging countries like China, and the uptrend in global oil prices.  These external factors will unfortunately continue to impact us and are likely to raise domestic prices further in the coming months.

 

     The best way to help Singaporeans to manage these increases in the costs of living is to grow the economy in a sustainable way and raise our skills, so as to help wages grow.  That remains our central strategy.  However, for households who are not earning any income from work, including most elderly households, inflation is always a problem.  The Government is mindful of the problems these households face, and has provided them with significant assistance over the last year – in fact exceeding the increase in costs of living they have faced. Take for example a retiree couple, living in a 3-room flat.  They would have received a total of $1,200 in benefits last year.  This would have exceeded the total increase in costs that such households would have faced as a result of rising food, utilities

Column: 1973

and other prices.  If they were living with children who are low-income earners, the assistance provided by the Government would also be considerably greater, as the household would have received Workfare Income Supplement (WIS).  The WIS would have gone to the working child, if he or she had a low income.

 

     This approach will continue in the upcoming Budget.  The Government will take into account the impact of inflation and the needs of low-income and retiree households when considering further transfers.

 

     Ms Irene Ng and Mdm Ho Geok Choo had also asked about the outlook for interest rates and what can be done to help Singaporeans, especially the low-income and elderly, get more returns on their savings.  The current low level of interest rates reflects loose global liquidity conditions.  We do not make official forecasts of interest rates, but market analysts believe that this low interest rate environment could persist for a while in view of the still weak recovery of the US and other developed economies.

 

     However, low-income savers in Singapore are in fact less affected by bank deposit rates than our CPF interest rates.  Apart from the homes they live in, CPF savings are the main source of retirement funds for low- and middle-income Singaporeans.  CPF interest rates are currently significantly higher than bank deposit rates.  This is especially so for the first $60,000 of a member’s balances, which currently earn an interest rate of 3.5% if the money is in the Ordinary Account, and 5% if it is in the Special, Medisave or Retirement accounts.   So 3.5% and 5% in a member's CPF accounts for the first $60,000, which are significantly above bank interest rates.   

 

     For Singaporeans who do not have significant spare savings – which include

Column: 1974

many of our retirees – it remains best for them to keep their investments simple and conservative.  It has been and remains unwise for them to seek higher returns by investing in high risk assets.  As Members know, through the MoneySENSE financial education programme, we have been seeking to help more Singaporeans plan for retirement and invest their spare savings prudently.

 

     Our capital markets are also developing and offering more investment alternatives.  These include instruments that offer better returns than savings deposits but without overly high risk.  Retail investors can now participate in Singapore Government Securities (SGS) auctions via ATMs of the three local banks.  By the middle of this year, they will also be able to buy and sell SGS on the Singapore Exchange.  Well-rated corporate bonds are also becoming more widely available, as high quality borrowers are turning more to the bond market to meet their financing needs.  Some of these companies have begun to issue bonds aimed at retail investors, and we can expect this to be a growing trend in coming years.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Mr Speaker, according to the latest household expenditure survey, HDB residents spent up to 36% of their household expenditure on food including hawker fare.  So any increase in the food prices is felt keenly.  Is the Minister aware that in recent weeks, the cost of a cup of coffee has gone up by five cents to 20 cents in some food courts, attributed to global price hikes in sugar and coffee?  Is the Minister also aware that the privatisation of hawker centres and coffee shops to large chains has led to higher prices?  Nasi padang in some food courts can cost more than five dollars.  Can the Minister assure us that food prices remain affordable, especially to people with modest income, and that businesses will

Column: 1975

not use inflation as an excuse to jack up prices and profiteer?

 

     The Minister spoke about investing prudently.  Can the Minister address the trend of banks encouraging people to spend and to incur debts with easy credit and promotions rather than to save and to invest prudently?  And does the Minister agree that the surge in the number of credit cards per person and the growth of rollover balances are danger signs that people are being ensnared in the cycle of debt?

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  Sir, food price inflation is a concern.  In November, it was already about 1.8% higher than it was a year earlier and it is likely to rise in the coming months for the reasons I mentioned.  Several key commodities are seeing prices go up significantly in global markets: sugar, which partly accounts for prices at coffee shops going up, coffee itself, wheat, soy beans and several other commodities.  This will impact us.


     We will take into account all factors when we look at the needs of the poor and the elderly, who tend to spend more of their cash on food items compared to middle- and higher-income households.  We will take into account their needs.


     Whether or not prices are going up too rapidly in response to higher import costs, this is something we always monitor.  The Ministry of Trade and Industry has a committee that looks into profiteering.  Minister of State Lee Yi Shyan heads it.  If the Member finds something unusual happening in her neighbourhood, it is useful to pass on the information.


     The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) keeps looking at how banks go about their marketing strategies for credit cards as well as consumer debt generally, both from the point of view of ensuring proper professional practices and also to

Column: 1976

make sure that people are not over-extending themselves.  Our rules on credit cards and consumer credit are more conservative than in most countries including those in Asia.  We limit consumer credit based on how much income you earn.  You cannot borrow on credit cards unless you have a minimum income level.  But it is something we are watching closely and if Members notice anything that struck them as especially sharp –  aggressive marketing practices on the part of banks –  it is useful to provide some feedback to the MAS and they will take a look.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast):  Mr Speaker, I would like to ask the Minister three supplementary questions.  Would the Minister consider commissioning a survey which would allow policymakers to assess how low interest rates are affecting ordinary households?  Has the Government done a survey to see what companies, themselves, are doing to prevent prices from rising too quickly especially businesses engaged in daily consumables and transportation?  What can the Government do to help these businesses?

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  There is no harm in having a survey to see if it provides a picture different from what the national statistics show.  The Ministry of Trade and Industry is in charge of this,  but those of us in Government are familiar with how the Department of Statistics goes about its work.  The CPI has integrity.  It is a robust process of sampling, every so many years, of the household expenditure basket; and they measure prices constantly.  The figure I mentioned earlier – for instance for food in November, the average household food expenditure for a set basket of items faced prices that were 1.8% higher than a year ago  –  that is correct.  We will be able to find individual items that went up much faster – whether it be cooked food in hawker centres or items of raw food that you are buying from the

Column: 1977

supermarkets or wet markets.  But, on average, it went up by 1.8%.  We think it is going to go up further.  We are concerned about this and we will be studying this to see how we can help households, particularly the low-income households and the elderly.

     Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar):  Mr Speaker, the Minister said earlier that any rise in the cost of living will cause the greatest impact on the lower income families and retirees.  In fact, some of them may spend as much as 50% of their monthly income on food.  May I ask the Minister's response to the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organisation's (FAO) warning on record food prices?  What kind of reassurance can I get from the Minister that his Ministry understands the plight of our residents especially those on meagre incomes?  Is there any urgent assistance funding available to prevent hardship and hunger for the low-income families?

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  Dr Lily Neo referred to the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) which has been monitoring prices, and which issued a statement recently expressing concern about what is happening in world markets.  They were particularly concerned about the impact on the poorest countries in Africa and elsewhere.  I think in this part of the world, although economic growth is rapid, we are also facing problems of our own – coming out of high demand in China and some weather-related disruptions.  Fortunately, we are not as much  a consumer of wheat as we are of rice, but nevertheless there is a certain amount of wheat that goes into the household basket in one way or another, and various other products like sugar and so on.  We are concerned about it.  As I mentioned, the increase in the average household expenditure basket as a result of CPI increases has not been too

Column: 1978

significant so far but we are watching it  and we think it will go up further.


     In the Budget, we will take all this into account in deciding what assistance we should provide to households, in particular the poor and the elderly.  As the Member knows, we also have ComCare and other schemes which allow residents who are truly in need to get assistance.  That is not something we are short of.  ComCare is well funded.  We will take another look at this in the Budget.

Column: 1978

MEASURES TO HELP SINGAPOREANS COPE WITH SLOWER ECONOMIC GROWTH

     3.  Mrs Mildred Tan asked the Minister for Trade and Industry in view that Singapore is likely to hit a high growth of around 15% this year and an anticipated drop of about 10% next year (a) what measures are being put in place to help Singaporeans prepare for the road ahead; and (b) what measures and initiatives will be introduced to help stimulate growth.

     The Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr S Iswaran) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry):  Mr Speaker, Sir, last year’s GDP growth of almost 15% was exceptional and it is not an appropriate indication of Singapore's long-term growth potential.  Rather, it reflects a recovery following two years of below-trend growth, coupled with an extremely large expansion in pharmaceutical output and the opening of the Integrated Resorts.  If we take an average of economic growth over the last three years, that is 2008 to 2010, it would come to about 5% per annum, which is more reflective of the economy’s underlying potential.

 

     This year’s expected growth of 4% to 6% is still above our medium-term growth potential of around 3% to 5% per annum.  This healthy rate of growth will support job creation and wage growth in both

Column: 1979

manufacturing and services industries.There is no need for stimulus measures. If anything, we need to be watchful of over-heating risks and raising inflationary pressures, as the labour market tightens and capacity constraints become more binding.

 

     With the economy at full employment, the emphasis will be on raising the productivity of our workforce and increasing economic competitiveness over the medium term. The Government has been working with businesses and unions to put in place several initiatives to boost skills and innovation. A good example is the Workfare Training Support scheme, which will pay for up to 95% of course fees and provide training commitment awards for older low-wage workers. NTUC has launched the Inclusive Growth Programme (IGP) to drive productivity improvements. The programme targets to benefit 25,000 low-wage workers over the next two years by helping them acquire new skills to handle higher-value jobs. 

 

     The Government will also help to raise corporate capabilities. The National Productivity and Continuing Education Council (NPCEC), chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean and comprising representatives from the unions and the public and private sectors, has endorsed a number of initiatives to raise productivity. One of these is the SME-Productivity Roadmap, a joint initiative by SPRING Singapore and the Singapore Workforce Development Agency. This initiative will help Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) identify weaknesses in their work processes and embark on suitable training courses to increase their productivity. Another example is the Construction Productivity and Capability Fund. Builders can apply to the Building and Construction Authority to fund 50% to 80% of costs incurred for manpower development, technology adoption, and capability building.    

Column: 1980


     To boost innovation and R&D in the economy, the Government will invest a further $16.1 billion over the next five years in research, innovation and enterprise. We will also focus on enhancing the alignment between research carried out in our laboratories and the commercialisation needs of our industry. We will continue to support foundational research to seed the intellectual capital that is necessary for future innovations.

 

     In addition, we aim to strengthen our position as a leading financial and business hub by attracting new companies, particularly those who are keen to take advantage of rising opportunities in Asia. For example, we are developing Singapore as a leading Asian Consumers' Business Centre, by anchoring the regional operations of major consumer products companies here. Global players that have been successfully attracted include Unilever, Procter & Gamble and Nestle. In fact, Unilever's headquarter in Singapore is its largest outside London.

 

     If we continue to do these things well, Singapore should be able to sustain 3% to 5% growth over the medium term and consequently increase its standard of living for Singaporeans.

Column: 1980

PRODUCTIVITY OF FOREIGN WORKFORCE

     4.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Trade and Industry how does the productivity of the foreign workforce in Singapore compare with the productivity of the local workforce for the years 2009 and 2010.

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Lee Yi Shyan) (for the Minister of Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, labour productivity is the value of output each worker produces. It is measured by taking the total value-

Column: 1981

added and dividing it by the number of workers. Currently, our national productivity data is obtained by aggregating the output of industries and dividing it over the workers employed. As industries and firms do not submit data showing separately output value by local and foreign workers, our aggregate data too would not be able to distinguish productivity due to local or foreign workers as separate measurements.

 

     This said, every worker who is added to the workforce will either raise or reduce the collective productivity of the workforce, regardless whether they are local or foreign. This is why the Government emphasises the importance of skills upgrading and productivity improvement for the entire workforce.  

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo: Thank you, Minister of State for the comprehensive response. I have one question: with the Government slowing down the influx of foreigners, have our economic growth targets changed? What alternative strategic plans do we have to attain those targets?

     Mr Lee Yi Shyan: We have made it quite clear that the strategy for sustained growth for Singapore is through raising productivity. Therefore, my colleague, Senior Minister of State Iswaran has detailed a number of initiatives guided by the NPCEC, as to how various sectors can continue to map out their plans for productivity improvements. An appropriate supply of foreign workforce and workers in the right number at the right quality will help us achieve that purpose.

Column: 1981

IMPACT OF WIKILEAKS REVELATIONS

(Home Affairs perspective)

     5.  Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) whether

Column: 1982

there are plans to implement any new measures to prevent classified information or communications from falling into unauthorised hands, following the WikiLeaks incident; and (b) what is the Ministry's assessment of our current information security policies and tools used in the Civil Service.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr K Shanmugam): Sir, in Singapore, we have clear policies and measures to prevent security breaches in the handling of official secrets or classified information. There are also clear laws on the penalties which apply, should there be a breach. 


     Every officer undergoes security clearance before being employed by the public service. He is also informed that access to classified information is granted on a need-to-know basis. He is required to comply with the security requirements spelt out in the Government Instruction Manuals, and to sign the undertaking to safeguard official information under the Official Secrets Act.


     Government agencies are also responsible for implementing measures to ensure strict user access control for all systems. For example, only official authorised systems, secured with appropriate encryption and authentication mechanisms, may be used to transmit and store classified information. Agencies are also required to conduct periodic checks and audits to ensure compliance with the security requirements.


     Permanent Secretaries of Ministries and Heads of Government Departments and Statutory Boards are responsible not only for ensuring that their officers comply with the security requirements, but also for setting the right tone in their respective organisations.


     But even with comprehensive measures in place, protection of classified

Column: 1983

information ultimately depends on each public officer observing the rules.


     Our Government is an e-Government. It cannot function without empowering our public servants and disseminating confidential information to them. The efficient functioning of our Government has to be based on mutual trust and honour, backed up by a clear legal framework. Trust and honour can of course be breached. As the WikiLeaks incident shows, even one officer, in that instance a junior officer in the US Army, can cause significant leak of official data with far-reaching consequences.


     Should there be any leak, the Government will act firmly. All cases will be investigated. Officers responsible for leakage of data will be charged. Furthermore, the OSA allows prosecution not only of public officers responsible for the leaks, but also anyone else (whether or not a public servant) who receives the information or had any role in the leak. The Government has consistently taken this approach, and has on occasions charged private citizens for their roles in leakage of Government data.


     In the US, the Shield Bill has been introduced in response to the WikiLeaks disclosure. It seeks to tighten up on leaks and the publication of such leaks. The Shield Bill proposes to apply to all, including non-government employees. Opponents of the Shield Bill argue that while it is illegal for government officials to leak information, it should nevertheless not be unlawful for the media and others to publish such information, that is, too bad if the government cannot prevent the information from leaking in the first place. For example, Professor Stone, a distinguished legal scholar in this field, took that position in an opinion published in the International Herald Tribune on 5th January 2011.


     In such a framework, confidential information will become the object of a

Column: 1984

cat and mouse game. If some government employee breaches the rules, and gets the information to the private sector, then tough luck to the government! This approach has been justified on the basis that it is in the public interest not to restrict free flow of information.


     Our approach is totally different. If recipients of official information who are not themselves public servants cannot be prosecuted or prevented from publishing it, it would create an unacceptable situation where people outside the Government would have every incentive to obtain confidential information from public servants in every way possible. And public servants would constantly be weighing the benefits to themselves of releasing the confidential information against the likelihood of getting caught and punished.  Meanwhile, the broader public interest will suffer.


     We believe that everyone involved in a leak of information, whether in Government or outside, should be dealt with firmly. We do not intend to encourage cat and mouse games. Public interest in free flow of information cannot justify the abuse of confidential information.


     Some countries have allowed their secrecy rules to be weakened in the belief that it is supposedly in the interest of freedom of information. We do not subscribe to such a belief. We fully intend to uphold confidentiality of official information, so that the Government can function properly. It is impossible to conduct diplomacy, develop policy or negotiate issues if everything said or written in the process will become public because officials will no longer commit their true thoughts and reasons in writing for fear of leaks. The end result, ironically, would be less transparency and less accountability.

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Hong Kah): Thank you for the Minister's reply. I think it is

Column: 1985

important that the public is also given the confidence that all the information pertaining to public information and private data is kept confidential. Could I ask the Minister if there are any changes to any policies and procedures within our Government, since the WikiLeaks incident?

     Mr Shanmugam: We had and will continue to have comprehensive policies in place, including directions and Government Instruction Manuals, and the very comprehensive green book as setting out what should and should not be done, which covers general situations. Bearing in mind – the Member will know – the WikiLeaks incident was caused by an officer abusing his position, and with no clear legal framework on what can and cannot be published when such leaks occur.


     We have the legal framework. Nevertheless, we do not sit back. Members might know that an organisation was set up for IT security and launched by Ministry of Home Affairs. That organisation looks at the entire Government sector, constantly reviewing the procedures and reminding officers and all Government public servants on the importance of safeguarding information. But, ultimately, we do not take anything for granted. The way that the leaks happened has meant that there has been continuing review after that as well. But at the end of the day, thousands of public servants get access to information and that is why I emphasised that it does depend on people observing the rules and being honourable. When they do not, we will act firmly.

IMPACT OF WIKILEAKS REVELATIONS

(Foreign Affairs perspective)

     6.  Ms Sylvia Lim asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs how the WikiLeaks

Column: 1986

revelations in November and December 2010 concerning statements purportedly made by Singapore's senior leaders and diplomats have affected our bilateral relations with ASEAN neighbours.

Particularly so when many of the leaks were the interpretations of the US diplomats on the conversations that they heard. Hence as a matter of principle, we have refrained from commenting on specific leaks.

 

     Singapore has long-standing, robust and positive relations with all countries in our region. These relationships are built on a strong foundation of shared interests and mutually beneficial cooperation in various areas. Countries would not allow WikiLeaks disclosures to affect their vital interests. In response to a protest submitted by Malaysia on the issue, which was conveyed to our High Commissioner in Kuala Lumpur on 14th December, I made a telephone call to my Malaysian counterpart, Dato’ Seri Anifah Aman to explain our policy of not commenting on specific leaks. I did tell him that there were significant inaccuracies in some of the leaked reports in the media. We agreed on the

Column: 1987

importance of good bilateral relations and strengthening cooperation further.

Column: 1988

us in their conversation. It is not even first-hand, and the original leaks have not been released.  So I think it is not wise for us to go into details; then, people will ask: did you say this, did you say that?  And if we allow such a train of questioning, then eventually everything comes out.  Now the US government is not going to comment on the accuracy, or the veracity or the basis for all these despatches, and that is our policy too.

But, these are based upon instincts or information that we pick up from here and there. So, yes, we have to be more guarded in our communication with US diplomats.  I think the WikiLeaks disclosures have been disastrous for US diplomacy. But, this applies to other forms of communication as well.  At the same

time, it is a loss because I think part of human relationships is that we must be able to share more when we trust somebody more.

RECENT INCREASE IN COE PRICES

     7.  Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Transport in view of the recent hike in the Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices (a) whether there is any evidence of  speculation;  (b)  what  measures,  if  any, are  being  taken  to control the sudden surge in COE prices; and (c) what is the expected trend of COE supply over the next 12 months.

     The Minister for Transport (Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat):  Sir, the COE system has been modified many times to curb speculation and increase its transparency since its introduction in 1990. Let me explain why speculation, or attempts to profiteer from the COE system, is not likely to be significant with the existing measures in place.

 

     Firstly, all COE bids made in the two car categories (Categories A and B) and the motorcycle category (Category D) must be made in the name of the buyers.

Column: 1990

Once the COE is obtained, the vehicle has to be registered in the name of the bidder.  Therefore, there must be a genuine buyer behind each bid, and the buyer cannot subsequently re-sell the COE to another buyer to profit from a rising COE market. In fact, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) has made the rules so tight that cars registered using Categories A and B COEs cannot be transferred within the first three months, and should the ownership of the car be transferred between the 4th and the 6th months, LTA would impose an additional levy to prevent any possible gain.  

 

     However, to provide some flexibility and convenience for those who require their vehicles urgently, successful COE bids in Category C (Goods Vehicles and Buses) and Category E (Open Category) in the name of individuals are transferable. However, these can only be transferred once within the first three months, while successful bids by companies are not transferable at all.
     
     To discourage speculators, especially for the Category E COEs, we have put in place a number of deterrent measures. In the past, there were instances of speculators with Category E COEs who, when caught in a falling COE market, limited their losses by using these COEs to register cheaper vehicles such as motorcycles and immediately de-register them to claim a near 100% COE rebate. To close this loophole, the COE rebate for vehicles registered using a Category E COE is now computed based on the lower of the Category E COE price or that of the corresponding vehicle category in the same tender exercise, and any pro-rated COE rebate is also subject to an 80% cap if the vehicle is de-registered for export within two years from registration.

 

     While these measures do not make it completely impossible to speculate in Category E COEs, we must also bear in mind that any would-be speculator must

Column: 1991

be prepared to fork out $10,000 for the COE bid deposit. They would then have at most three months of the COE validity period to try to sell off the COE for a profit, failing which they would lose the $10,000 deposit. The full details of the existing anti-speculation measures can be found at the LTA website.

 

     Dr Lim asked if any measures will be taken to control the surge in COE prices. The objective of the COE system is to ensure that the vehicle population grows at a sustainable rate so that our roads do not become gridlocked. The supply of COEs is fixed by the quota which takes into account the allowable vehicle growth rate, the actual vehicle de-registrations in the preceding period and the one-time adjustments to compensate for over-projections in de-registrations in 2008 and 2009 under the old methodology. The quota is subsequently distributed through a bidding system, and the prices for the COEs are ultimately determined by the supply of COEs, and the demand for them. In 2010, the supply of COEs was reduced due to the relatively lower de-registrations and the adjustments. This reduction in supply, together with the rising demand for COEs in a strong economy, naturally pushed prices up.

 

     LTA has carefully studied the many suggestions given by the public and motor industry recently. In particular, the Motor Traders' Association (MTA) suggested spreading out the adjustments for the over-projections over a longer period. LTA is prepared to do so, to give the industry and car buyers more time to adjust. These are one-time corrections, and will not affect the long-term growth in the vehicle population. LTA will therefore spread out the remaining 9,577 COEs to be corrected over a period of three years, instead of the remaining one year. This will be factored into the quotas for the bidding period of February 2011 to July 2011, which LTA will announce later today.

 

Column: 1992

     Dr Lim asked about the expected trend of COE supply in the next 12 months. The LTA no longer forecasts future COE supply. However, it has been providing updated information on the latest monthly de-registration data to help those who wish to make their own projections.

     Dr Lim Wee Kiak (Sembawang):  Sir, I would like to thank the Minister for the comprehensive reply.  I have two supplementary questions.

 

     First, the gyration of the COE prices.  There are years where more than 100,000 COEs are released, and there are years where fewer than 50,000 COEs are released.  Over the 10-year life cycle period, I would like to ask the Minister how does his Ministry intend to even out this sudden surge and sudden drop in COE supply, because this will result in the gyration of prices.

 

     Second, regarding some of the suggestions that were given by the public. Will the Ministry consider each COE as a separate bidding, which means that you pay as you bid?  That will actually control some of the elements whereby people will tend to outbid one another.  The other point is to limit COE financing so as to encourage prudence in car financing.

     Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat:  Sir, as explained earlier, the COE policy is to control the vehicle population growth rate.  This is to prevent, as I said, gridlock on our roads.  It is not a policy which seeks to stabilise COE prices.  We do not really control that because the bulk of the supply comes from de-registration.  So, it really depends on Singaporeans' decisions on whether to de-register their cars or not.

 

      On the second question raised, which is a suggestion on pay-as-you-bid, the GPC for Transport discussed this some years back.  It was a suggestion which they looked into in great detail and they

Column: 1993

came to the conclusion that there were certain shortcomings in the system.  It would add complexity to the system, in particular when you have one particular model with multiple values on it, depending on what you bid for the COE, because different bidders will pay different COE prices.   What was important was that they studied the spread of prices.  Right now, we have the lowest successful bid which clears the COE quota.  When they looked at the spread, they found that there was a clustering towards the lowest successful bid, about 20%-30% above it.  LTA looked at it again, and again the clustering was there.  It was not as though the highest bidders were pulling up all the prices. 

 

     The Member's final question was on COE financing.   MAS has looked into this, and studied this.  There is no evidence that existing car loan financing rules that are in place pose a systemic threat to the financial system.  The non-performing loan is extremely small.  So MAS, at this stage, will not be acting to change the car financing rules but expects financial institutions to, of course, exercise prudence when granting car loans.

ACCIDENTS ALONG MRT AND LRT TRACKS

     8.  Mr  Zaqy  Mohamad asked  the  Minister  for Transport  (a)  if he would provide an update on the number of accidents involving passengers and service staff falling or being on MRT and LRT tracks over the past three years; (b) what measures have been put in place to reduce such passenger and  work accidents; and (c) whether the Ministry will consider bringing forward the installation of platform screens at passenger interchanges such as Choa Chu Kang MRT station, which serves as a node for MRT, LRT and bus services.  

Column: 1994

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr Teo Ser Luck) (for the Minister for Transport):   Sir, from 2008 to 2010, there were 73 incidents of commuter track intrusions on our MRT and LRT systems.  Of these, 51 or 70% were deliberate, with passengers going onto the tracks to retrieve dropped items, or crossing the tracks as a shortcut.  The remaining 22 cases or 30% were accidental, typically involving commuters that fall onto the track due to some illness.  In the same period, there were two accidents involving service staff on train tracks. 


     Safety procedures are put in place to ensure safety for all rail commuters and service staff.  Works on tracks and guideways are governed by track access procedures and safety procedures to ensure work safety for staff.  Areas that are safe for access are clearly demarcated.  Should there be a need for service staff to encroach into areas outside of these boundaries, the train Operation and Control Centre (OCC) will hold all trains stationary before the access is authorised.

  
     For commuters on the station platforms, the operators regularly broadcast safety reminders for passengers to wait behind the yellow lines on the platforms, and station Customer Service Officers (CSOs) at platforms to ensure that passengers do not rush onto the trains.  Train drivers are also trained to keep a lookout for potentially dangerous situations and to take preventive actions when necessary. 


     In spite of these measures, accidents sometimes occur.  We view these incidents seriously, and require the operators to submit reports identifying the causes of the incident and the safety mitigation actions to avoid similar occurrences in the future.

Column: 1995


     As Member Mr Zaqy Mohamad has highlighted, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) is also in the process of installing Half Height Platform Screen Doors (HHPSD) at all 36 elevated MRT stations of the North-South and East-West Lines (NSEWL).  The installations are targeted for completion by 2012.  To date, the platform screen doors are operational at nine MRT stations: Pasir Ris, Yishun, Jurong East, Clementi, Bukit Gombak, Lakeside, Bukit Batok, Chinese Garden and Eunos.  More are on the way very soon.


     Carrying out platform screen door installations on an operational MRT Line is a challenging task.  Installation work can only commence after revenue service hours, so that daily train operations are not affected.  Works are therefore limited to a narrow window of about two-three hours each night.  We seek the public's patience and understanding on this, and remain committed to completing the installation of the platform screen doors as soon as possible. 


     LTA has prioritised the installation works by targeting more crowded MRT stations such as Jurong East, Clementi and Yishun.  Priority was also given to the East-West Line as it has more elevated stations than the North-South Line.  We expect work on the East-West Line stations to be completed by the third quarter of this year.  Works for Choa Chu Kang Station, which is on the North-South Line, are scheduled to commence later this year, for completion by mid-2012.

MINIMUM AGE REQUIREMENT FOR FOREIGN DOMESTIC WORKERS

     9.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Manpower (a) how the Ministry ensures that maid  agencies comply with the minimum age requirement for the employment of foreign domestic workers; (b) whether the Ministry will consider reducing the minimum age requirement from 23 years to

Column: 1996

21 years to protect young foreign domestic workers and ensure better compliance with the minimum age requirement;  and (c) what recourse and protection do employers have against maid agencies that flout this requirement. 

     The Minister of State for Manpower (Mr Lee Yi Shyan) (for the Minister for Manpower):  Mr Speaker, Sir, on 1st January 2005, MOM raised the minimum age of foreign domestic workers (FDWs) from 18 to 23 years, as older FDWs are generally more responsible, and are better able to take care of themselves and adapt to the working environment in a foreign country.  MOM's studies have shown that FDWs above the age of 23 are more likely to settle in well.   
     
     Since then, the number of unnatural deaths involving FDWs has fallen from an annual average of 30 for 2002 to 2005, to an annual average of 20 from 2006 to 2010.  The annual number of reported abuse cases has also fallen by more than 20%, from 217 cases in 2001 to 167 in 2009.  This is despite an increase in the FDW population by almost a third since 2005. 
    
     In order to hold an employment agency licence, employment agencies are required to ensure that the workers they bring in meet MOM's entry requirements.  As the first point of contact for FDWs, and the intermediary between FDWs and employers, employment agencies are expected to exercise due diligence in verifying the age of FDWs.  This includes checking the details in their official documents such as their passports, birth documents and educational certificates, as well as interviewing FDWs to ensure that the information they provide at the interviews is consistent with the information in their official documents. 


     MOM actively investigates and takes action against negligent employment agencies that fail to meet these

Column: 1997

requirements.  Last year, 14 employment agencies were warned for bringing in under-aged FDWs, of which four were issued demerit points as well.  Action taken against some of these agencies stemmed from information provided by the under-aged FDWs themselves, who were not prosecuted.  The new employment agency regulatory framework that MOM hopes to implement on 1st April this year aims to further tighten regulations on errant employment agencies, and raise the professionalism and service standards of the employment agency industry.

 

     In addition, staff at MOM's Work Pass Services Centre interview FDWs who appear especially young to verify their application details when they arrive for fingerprinting.  FDWs found to be under-aged will not be allowed to work here.  However, as the passport is an official document issued by the source country authorities, it is the primary document for identification and age verification.  It is therefore important for these authorities in the source countries to ensure that the information contained in such documents is accurate.

 

     Reducing the minimum age requirement will not address the problems faced by young FDWs.  Lowering the minimum age requirement to 21 may even lead to the perverse outcome of making it easier for even younger girls to circumvent the minimum age requirement.  MOM will continue to step up its surveillance and enforcement efforts.  The authorities in the source countries also need to do their part to regulate their employment agencies and ensure the accuracy of information in their official documents.  We will work with embassies to encourage accuracy in official documents and enforcement against errant employment agencies in source countries.  Employers and other members of the public can also help by

Column: 1998

informing MOM if they suspect that an FDW in Singapore may be under-aged.

 

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):   Two supplementary questions for the Minister of State.  First, on reducing the age from 23 years to 21 years and the argument of the Minister of State that this will result in even younger FDWs being brought in. But as it is, we already have those as young as 16 years old being brought in.  I do not see the correlation in reducing the age from 23 to 21 and therefore having even younger foreign domestic workers being brought in, but at least the supply of the foreign domestic workers can be increased if the age limit is brought down to 21 years, without compromising the safety and welfare of these domestic workers.  My second point is, as the Minister of State has said, the official travel document is the source of information and how can we ensure that employment agencies will bring in maids who are not under-aged because that is the same argument that they are using in citing the fact that they be made responsible for under-aged domestic maids to be brought into Singapore.

 

     Mr Lee Yi Shyan:  Sir, I thank the Member for raising the two clarifications.  I think it is common logic to say that if the requirement age is 23 years,  to judge whether someone is under-aged against 23 years will be easier than to judge against 21 years, for the same under-aged worker that one intends to bring in.  Already today, given that this is the requirement, many employment agencies and potential employers cannot really tell the difference in age if the under-aged person is not far from the requirement age.  Therefore, we do not see how by reducing the age from 23 years to 21 years can help in detecting under-aged FDWs.  Our past data also suggested that many FDWs who had a great deal of adjustment problems were FDWs of age 23 years and below.  In fact, a number of them who fell to death from heights were

Column: 1999

around that age band.  So cutting the requirement age at 23 years was a deliberate move in 2005, and I think we should stick to that. 

 

     The Member also raised a supply issue.  We do not think supply is an issue at this point.  I think quality of supply is what we should pay attention to.  In fact, for FDWs who want to work in Singapore, we have introduced a number of measures, including requiring them to take a basic test to show their literacy and numeracy skills, and their ability to understand basic instructions on safety.  Also, we require first-time FDWs to take a four-hour orientation programme to be aware of their rights and to understand safety precautions surrounding their work environment.  So these are additional measures that we have introduced to help first-time FDWs adjust to the Singapore environment. 

 

     As to employment agencies saying they are relying on official documents as proof of age, we know that the source document is very important.  We are working with foreign embassies to ensure that the source document can be verified.  However, we also want our employment agencies to go beyond just relying on documentary proof, and to conduct investigative interviews upfront so that through interviews, we can find out if the workers have the right experience, if they indeed have finished school, if they indeed have worked for a number of years, and whether the evidence presented by them is contradictory.  So we have to rely on a number of measures to make sure that the under-aged workers do not come in.  Over the last few years, we have repatriated about 50 FDWs each year because they were underage.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:  If I could just follow up on the point about reducing the age from 23 years to 21 years – I think the criteria should be the level of capability/ability to handle stress on the

Column: 2000

part of the domestic workers, and not really the number among them that have committed suicide.  That is the reason why at the age of 21, and in Singapore, as you know, a lot of people are already assuming a lot of responsibilities at the age of 21.  But the issue of supply, in my view, has a direct correlation to the domestic workers being brought in who are under-aged.  Could the Minister of State still consider that possibility?

 

     Mr Lee Yi Shyan:  Sir, I agree with Mdm Halimah's point that the qualitative aspect and the maturity of the FDW to be brought in are our ultimate concerns.  Given that many of these workers do not grow up in our kind of urban environment and are not necessarily exposed to the requirements of modernity, some of them really have problems just operating washing machines, microwaves, and so on, not to mention working in high-rise buildings and cleaning windows.  This is a very different environment from where they came from. 


So I think that age is one important criterion but it is not the only criterion.  We have to look at a number of factors.  We have no intention of changing the age limit to lower it to qualify FDWs, but it can be a factor for future consideration.

Column: 2001

to the needy citizens households who are unable to afford home ownership flats and who have no family support or no alternative housing options.  There was an average of 2,700 rental applicants per year registered by HDB in the last three years.  In 2010, 83% of these applicants were family households while the remaining 17% were registered under the Joint Singles scheme.  Forty-four percent of them earned below $800 a month while 56% earned between $800 and $1,500 a month.

POSTAL DELIVERY SERVICES

(Level of customer satisfaction)

    14.  Mr Arthur Fong asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts for an assessment of the level of satisfaction of the postal services especially after the non-delivery of mail on weekends and the many complaints from residents.

     The Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (RAdm [NS] Lui Tuck Yew):  Mr Speaker, Sir, let me thank Mr Arthur Fong for his question on the postal delivery service.

   

     The Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) actively monitors the level of customer satisfaction with the postal delivery service and, indeed, we have observed an increase in the number of complaints in the second half of last year.  These complaints relate to both mail and parcel delivery.

 

     Basic mail delivery service is licensed.  As a Public Postal Licensee, SingPost is required to comply with the Quality of Service (QoS) standards set by IDA for

Column: 2011

the delivery of ordinary mail.  Ordinary mail is defined as basic letters that weigh up to 500 grams.  The QoS standards require 99% and 98% of local ordinary mail posted before stipulated collection times, to be delivered by the next working day for destinations within and outside the Central Business District (CBD) respectively.  So, 99% for destinations within the CBD by the next working day and 98% for mail collected to be delivered by the next working day for those outside the CBD and, of course, for both areas 100% of the mail to be delivered by the second working day.  There are also other QoS standards for the local processing of foreign ordinary mail.  All QoS standards are measured monthly and reviewed on a quarterly basis.

 

     SingPost has been complying with the QoS standards, including after the implementation of the five-day mail collection and delivery service implemented in May 2010.  While there had been 108 complaints to IDA, SingPost and the media on late or lost ordinary mail between July and December of last year, it should be taken into perspective that SingPost delivers more than 60 million mail items on a monthly basis.

 

     Parcel delivery does not require a licence from IDA.  The parcel delivery market is fully liberalised and is a competitive one with many service providers besides SingPost, including both local and foreign operators, such as Federal Express, United Parcel Services, DHL, TNT, Swiss Post, Royal Mail, Deutsche Post and Sweden Post.  With the availability of competitive options for consumers, IDA believes that market forces will compel operators to provide high quality parcel delivery services to consumers.

 

     In view of the increase in the number of complaints in the second half of last year, IDA had asked SingPost to review

Column: 2012

its delivery processes.  SingPost has identified two key causes for the recent service lapses: firstly, a higher-than-usual attrition rate in postal staff, and secondly, a substantial increase in overall parcel volume in the second half of last year.  SingPost has publicly acknowledged these issues and shared their measures for improvements.  These include stepping up the recruitment of postmen and postal workers as well as conducting additional and more stringent quality checks to minimise sorting errors and mis-deliveries.

 

     To meet increasing consumer needs and expectations, SingPost has also informed IDA that it will implement several improvements to its delivery and operational procedures, such as re-designing the work processes at delivery bases, improving the workflow for handling mis-sorted mail, and increasing the number of collection trips, just to name a few of them.  IDA is also reviewing the QoS standards imposed on SingPost and enhancing audits on its delivery service.
 
     I also understand that the public has been concerned whether SingPost’s move to a five-day mail collection and delivery service has impacted postal service quality.  A five-day mail service is not uncommon globally.  More than 70 countries have implemented a five-day mail service, including countries such as Australia, Canada, Sweden and Malaysia, just to name a few.  This was a result of declining mail volumes and changing mailing habits, driven by the increased use of alternative forms of communication like email and SMS, and the trend of more companies adopting a five-day work week.  The five-day mail service has in fact served to optimise postal resources and provide a more family-friendly work week for postmen working in this physically demanding industry.

 

     I would like to assure this House that IDA will continue to ensure that SingPost

Column: 2013

improves its delivery processes so that the public’s postal needs are met.

ALLIED HEALTH PROFESSIONS BILL

 

     Order for Second Reading read. 

 

     The Minister for Health (Mr Khaw Boon Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

 

     The Allied Health Professions Bill establishes a regulatory body, the Allied Health Professions Council, to register and regulate the allied health professionals, and prohibits false representation of these professionals.

 

     The Allied Health Professions comprise diverse groups of healthcare professionals providing a wide range of health services.

Column: 2015

They include radiographers, physiotherapists, occupational therapists, psychologists, speech therapists, and many others.

 

     With a rapidly ageing population, demand for healthcare will rise as the sick elderly are more likely to present with many diseases and more complex conditions. We are reforming our healthcare system to cope with the challenges in two major areas. First, we are strengthening the community and step-down care sector so that patients can be treated there competently instead of in costly acute hospitals. Second, doctors will increasingly be assisted by multi-disciplinary healthcare teams with allied health professionals as key partners. Success of these reforms relies on well-trained allied health professionals.
 
     These health professionals, with their specialised know-how, can contribute to better health outcomes and lower healthcare costs through effective rehabilitation, health promotion and prevention. For example, a physiotherapist is skilled in the physical rehabilitation of stroke patients or those who had undergone hip replacement, helping them to walk again. An occupational therapist is best placed to train the patient to perform self-care activities safely and independently, such as dressing himself, toileting and bathing. These rehabilitative activities are essential in helping the elderly regain an active and meaningful life.
 
     For a long time, we have left the allied health professions to regulate themselves. This was somewhat adequate in the past as most of them worked in the public sector and the professional bodies had diligently taken on a voluntary regulatory role.  However, as the demand for their services grows and as we try to build up the long-term care sector, the voluntary approach to regulation will become less effective. Voluntary self-regulation is also

Column: 2016

not the international norm.  All developed countries have legislations to regulate their allied health professions and they have been doing so for years.  Singapore is an outlier.
 
     I signalled this intent to regulate the allied health professions in 2007 when I came to this House to move the Optometrists and Opticians Bill.  The experience to regulate the optometrists and opticians has been positive. We are now better assured that these eye-care practitioners have the competencies to provide safe and effective eye-care services. Since then, the Optometrists and Opticians Board has registered more than 2,300 optometrists and opticians and will be implementing mandatory continuing professional education. This is a significant improvement from the past where untrained persons could easily set up shop and provide optometry services with sometimes questionable standards.

 

Our approach to regulation

 

     The next major group are the therapy professions: physiotherapists, occupational therapists and speech therapists. MOH could establish another legislation to target this group but there are many more allied health professions, like the dietitians, radiographers and psychologists. Such a piecemeal approach will take a long time.  Instead, we recommend the more efficient option of an umbrella legislation that will allow for the regulation of many allied health groups, with subsidiary legislations covering individual professions. The United Kingdom, New Zealand and Hong Kong have taken such an approach and this is the approach which is incorporated in this Bill. Let me now elaborate on the key features.
 
Main features of Bill

 

     Part I lays out the scope of application for the Bill where clause 4 clarifies that

Column: 2017

the Bill applies only to Allied Health Professions listed in the Second Schedule. As a start, only the occupational therapists, physiotherapists and speech therapists will be regulated. Clause 5 empowers the Minister for Health to amend the Schedule to regulate other allied health professions in future.
 
     Part II of the Bill sets up the Allied Health Professions Council, provides for members of the Council to be appointed by the Minister for Health, and to include representatives from each of the regulated allied health professions. The Council's functions are set out in clause 7, and include registration, issuing of practising certificates, and setting of standards for training, conduct and practice.
 
     There have been concerns raised regarding adequate representation of the different professions and the effectiveness of a single regulator regulating many different professions. Clause 12 empowers the Council to appoint committees and professional boards. These committees and professional boards play a key role in advising and making recommendations to the Council with regard to the standards and issues arising in particular professions, and will comprise mainly members of the specific professions. Coupled with a representative Council, such a structure would ensure that each profession is adequately represented and the unique issues faced by specific professions can be addressed. However, for operational efficiency, the Council is expected to maintain oversight and management of the committees and boards, complaints, investigations and disciplinary processes.
 
     Part III of the Bill sets out the registration framework to recognise appropriately trained and qualified professionals for practice in Singapore,

Column: 2018

and empowers the Council to impose conditions and restrictions on registration, require mandatory continuing education, refuse registration, remove and restore names under specified circumstances. Clause 14 sets up the four registers, corresponding to the four types of registration and these are: Full, Restricted, Conditional, and Temporary registration.
 
     Clauses 16 to 19 set out the general criteria, conditions and restrictions that may be imposed in the four registration categories. The tiered registration framework enables the Council flexibility to register individuals according to their training and practice experience, whilst providing safeguards to protect the public.
 
     Let me now elaborate on the different tiers of registration.  An allied health professional with full registration may practise generally and without supervision in the profession in which he is registered. There will be a list of approved qualifications. These qualifications will be determined by the Council and established for each regulated profession in the regulations. Anyone who holds an approved qualification or passes the local qualifying examination in a regulated profession would be eligible for full registration.
 
     Clause 16 deals with full registration and requires an allied health professional to complete a period of supervised practice under conditional registration before being eligible for full registration. This allows the Council to make a more comprehensive assessment of the practitioner instead of relying only on his qualifications and credentials. Clause 16 also allows the Council to apply exceptions and give full registration directly to an individual who is clearly well-trained and competent. Where a person is not eligible for full registration, his application will be assessed for other registration categories.
 

Column: 2019

     Clause 17 deals with restricted registration. A practitioner who does not have an approved qualification but has been practising in Singapore; or who may have a post-graduate qualification in specific area of professional practice but does not have an approved basic qualification, is among those who will be eligible for restricted registration. Like full registration, an allied health professional on restricted registration can practise independently. However, restrictions are imposed on his scope, place of practice, or employment because of his qualifications, practice experience, or health issues. Before an individual is granted restricted registration, his abilities may also have to be assessed through conditional registration.
 
     Clause 18 deals with conditional registration. Conditional registration will generally be applied to all new registrants who have approved qualifications or have passed the local qualifying examinations. While under conditional registration, the practitioner will be supervised and subject to performance review. This enables the Council to make an assessment on the ability to practise safely and competently. The supervision requirement also ensures that new practitioners are adequately supported when they start working in Singapore.
 
     Temporary registration is set out in clause 19 and applies to an allied health professional who is in Singapore for the purpose of teaching, research or postgraduate study; or deemed to have knowledge, experience and skill of value to Singapore to function in any healthcare capacity, including the provision of health services, but is not otherwise entitled to be registered. To safeguard the public, a practitioner on temporary registration will require supervision at all times, and additional conditions and restrictions may also be imposed.

 

     Part IV of the Bill sets out the various offences and a penalty of a fine not

Column: 2020

exceeding $25,000 and/or prison term not exceeding six months for a first offence. This Part protects the public by prohibiting false representation of the regulated allied health professionals. There are inherent difficulties in regulating every aspect of practice in any profession as, naturally, overlaps occur in normal life and work. For example, both exercise trainers and physiotherapists prescribe exercises but for different purposes and to different types of clients.

 

     However, we recognise that allied health professionals are trained and qualified to deal with healthcare and patients, and the expectation from the public is with regard to such expertise and its expected treatment outcomes. With a register of such professionals and laws against false representation, patients are assured that they are receiving treatment from bona fide practitioners.
 
     Thus, clauses 29 and 30 make it an offence for a person who is not registered to imply that he is a qualified professional from the way he provides services, or use any title set out in the Second Schedule. Clauses 31 to 33 set out various offences to prohibit business owners and employers from making false claims that their employee is so qualified, and also holds the employee and his co-workers liable for such false claims.
 

     Part V of the Bill deals with disciplinary proceedings before a Complaints  Committee, Disciplinary Tribunal, Health Committee and interim orders committee inquiries. It provides for the Council to take action against the registered allied health professional on conduct and fitness to practise issues set out in clause 39, and also has in place appeals mechanisms for aggrieved parties. The clauses in this Part are substantially similar to the new Part VII of the Medical Registration Act.
 
     To support professional self regulation, the Complaints Committee and Disciplinary

Column: 2021

Tribunal set out in clauses 40 and 50 will have a majority of members from the profession register index in the same profession as the person being complained against. As some of the smaller professions may not have members of sufficient experience and expertise, clause 50 also provides for the Minister to make exceptions to the Disciplinary Tribunal members' appointment where it is expedient to do so. Senior legal professionals may also be appointed to the Tribunal.
 
     The Complaints Committee and Disciplinary Tribunal are empowered to make a wide range of orders to deal with matters. These include dismissing frivolous complaints; issuing letters of advice or warning; ordering the registered person to undergo treatment, or suspending his practice. These powers are set out in clauses 42, 49 and 53. In addition, the Disciplinary Tribunal is empowered to impose a penalty of up to $50,000 on a registrant.
 

     Part VI provides for miscellaneous clauses to support the Council in meeting its mandate, such as setting out the powers of the investigators, appointment of legal and medical assessors and allowing for composition of offences.


     Lastly, the First Schedule sets out the occupational groups defined as allied health professions, and the Second Schedule lists and describes the allied health professions to which the Bill applies to.
 
     In preparing this Bill, the Ministry has consulted the public, allied health professionals and their associations as well as employers. There is strong support for the Bill. We will continue to consult them as we refine the implementation plans and subsidiary legislation that will follow.
